__data__.text: Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam, an ethnic Indian Malaysian from Ipoh, was born in 1988 and was one of four siblings. He moved to Singapore for work despite his family's objections, becoming a security guard. In 2009, Nagaenthran was arrested at the Woodlands Checkpoint for carrying 42.72g of diamorphine. He initially confessed to knowingly transporting drugs but later claimed he was coerced. He was sentenced to death, which was upheld in 2011. However, in 2012, Singapore amended its death penalty laws, granting judges the discretion to sentence drug traffickers to life imprisonment with caning if they were merely couriers and had assisted narcotics police or had diminished responsibility due to mental illness. Nagaenthran applied for re-sentencing in 2013, citing clinical intellectual disability and mental illness.

Nagaenthran, an ethnic Indian Malaysian arrested in 2009 for drug trafficking, applied for re-sentencing in 2013, citing clinical intellectual disability and mental illness. However, he was found not to be intellectually disabled, and did not receive a certificate of substantive assistance from the Central Narcotics Bureau. Nagaenthran's re-sentencing application was dismissed in 2017, and his appeals to the Court of Appeal were dismissed in 2019. His clemency plea to the President of Singapore was also rejected in 2020, finalizing his death sentence.
